unnormalised: ### My Brush with a Silent Killer: Understanding Heart Health in Your 30s
normalised: ### My Brush with a Silent Killer: Understanding Heart Health in Your Thirties

unnormalised: It all started with a nagging fatigue. I, Rohan Verma, 32, always considered myself pretty fit. Played cricket every weekend, tried to eat healthy (mostly!), and generally didn’t worry much about my health. Then, about 6 months ago, I started feeling inexplicably tired. Chalked it up to work stress, late nights binge-watching Netflix, the usual suspects.
normalised: It all started with a nagging fatigue. I, Rohan Verma, thirty two, always considered myself pretty fit. Played cricket every weekend, tried to eat healthy (mostly!), and generally didn’t worry much about my health. Then, about six months ago, I started feeling inexplicably tired. Chalked it up to work stress, late nights binge-watching Netflix, the usual suspects.

unnormalised: But the fatigue persisted. It wasn’t just being tired after a long day; it was a bone-deep weariness that settled in even after a full night's sleep. Then came the shortness of breath. Climbing the 3 flights of stairs to my apartment in Bandra felt like scaling Mt. Everest. Something was definitely off.

unnormalised: My wife, Priya, being the practical one, insisted I see a doctor. I kept putting it off, you know, "it's just a phase," "I'll get back to my routine soon." Finally, after collapsing during a particularly intense game of gully cricket (much to the amusement, and concern, of my friends), I relented.

unnormalised: My GP, Dr. Sharma, ran some routine tests. Everything seemed normal, except for slightly elevated cholesterol. She shrugged it off, said it could be dietary and advised lifestyle changes. I tried, I really did. Cut down on the butter chicken (a tragedy, I know!), started jogging a bit more regularly. But the symptoms remained.

But the symptoms remained.

unnormalised: Then, one evening, I experienced chest pain. A sharp, stabbing pain that radiated down my left arm. Panic set in. This wasn't just fatigue anymore. We rushed to Lilavati Hospital.
normalised: Then, one evening, I experienced chest pain. A sharp, stabbing pain that radiated down my left arm. Panic set in. This wasn't just fatigue anymore. We rushed to Lilavati Hospital.

unnormalised: The ER doctor, Dr. Patel, a no-nonsense guy, ordered an ECG immediately. The results weren’t good. Turns out, I had a blockage in one of my coronary arteries. I was facing a heart attack. At 32!
normalised: The E-R doctor, Doctor Patel, a no-nonsense guy, ordered an E-C-G immediately. The results weren’t good. Turns out, I had a blockage in one of my coronary arteries. I was facing a heart attack. At thirty two!

unnormalised: The next few days were a blur of tests, consultations, and mounting anxiety. I learned about angiography, angioplasty, stents – words that were completely foreign to me just a week before. Dr. Patel explained that while I was relatively young, factors like family history (my grandfather had heart disease), stress, and even my fondness for oily street food contributed to the problem.

unnormalised: I underwent angioplasty. A small stent was inserted to open up the blocked artery. The procedure itself wasn't too bad, thankfully. The relief afterward was immense. The chest pain vanished, and I could breathe easier again.
normalised: I underwent angioplasty. A small stent was inserted to open up the blocked artery. The procedure itself wasn't too bad, thankfully. The relief afterward was immense. The chest pain vanished, and I could breathe easier again.

unnormalised: Recovery was slow but steady. I had to change my lifestyle drastically. I started taking medication, including a daily dose of Aspirin 75mg. I also began following a strict diet prescribed by the hospital’s dietician, and joined a cardiac rehab program.
normalised: Recovery was slow but steady. I had to change my lifestyle drastically. I started taking medication, including a daily dose of Aspirin seventy five milligrams. I also began following a strict diet prescribed by the hospital’s dietician, and joined a cardiac rehab program.

unnormalised: Now, several months later, I feel like a new person. I’m more aware of my body, my limitations, and the importance of taking care of my heart. My cardiologist, Dr. Menon, at the Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital, emphasizes the importance of regular check-ups, especially for those with a family history of heart disease. He recommends a lipid profile test every 6 months and an ECG every year.

unnormalised: My experience was a wake-up call. Heart disease isn’t just an old person’s problem. It can strike at any age. Early detection and lifestyle changes are key. So, if you're in your 30s, even if you feel healthy, please, get yourself checked. It could save your life. Remember, a healthy heart beats strong!
